subject: Re: [junit] What should I be testing?

messageBody:
On Wed, Aug 26, 2009 at 4:31 AM, rejohnsoca<regan.v.johnson@...> wrote:
>  I want to write a small utility to rename the pictures in a controllable way, but prefixing something like
> "RND", a set of random digits, and the original name.  For example, if the original was
> DCIM1001.jpg, I want the class to rename the file to "RND4356332_DCIM1001.jpg".

> I want to build this, using TDD.
> but my next question, is now what?

Hi Regan.

In this case I'd personally test and implement from the "outside in".
Meaning, I'd actually try and verify the end result we're after.

Conceptually, I'd write a functional (unit) test that:
a) In a temporary folder (JUnit 4.7's new TemporaryFolder interceptor
is just perfect for this!),
b) Create a bunch of files named DCIM????.jpg
c) Run PhotoRandomizer.doYourThing() on the temporary folder
d) Verify that all the files in the temporary folder are now named
"RND???????_DCIM????.jpg"

Before I even implement PhotoRandomizer, I can already think of a
couple of 'inner' methods that "can possibly break" such as generating
the random file name from an existing file, and actually renaming a
single file with a new, random file name.

So I'd write tests for those, make them pass, then make the
'outermost' test pass, and before you know it you have a working (or
at least workable) app.

My two cents,
- alistair
